subsection.title: Introduction
subsection.p: We have already encountered some examples of polynomial functions. Linear functions, f (x) = ax + b and quadratic functions f (x) = ax^2 + bx + c are special cases of polynomial functions. In general, we make the following definition.

definition.title: Polynomial Function
definition.p: A polynomial functionpolynomialfunctionfunctionpolynomial has the form f (x) = a_n x^n + a_{n-1}x^{n-1} + a_{n-2}x^{n-2} + \cdots + a_2x^2 + a_1x + a_0 where a_0, a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n are constants and a_n \ne 0. The coefficient a_n of the highest power term is called the lead coefficientlead coefficientpolynomiallead coefficient.

subsection.p: Some examples of polynomials are f(x)\amp= 6x^3 - 4x^2 + x - 2 \amp g(x) \amp= 9x^5 - 2 p(x) \amp = x^4 + x^2 + 1 \amp q(x) \amp= 2x^{10} - x^7 + 3x^6 + 5x^3 + 3x

Each of the polynomials above is written in descending powersdescending powers, which means that the highest-degree degree (of a polynomial) term comes first, and the degrees of the terms decrease from largest to smallest. Sometimes it is useful to write a polynomial in ascending powersascending powers, so that the degrees of the terms increase. For example, the polynomial f(x) above would be written as f(x) = -2 + x - 4x^2 + 6x^3 in ascending powers.

subsection.title: Products of Polynomials
subsection.p: When we multiply two or more polynomials together, we get another polynomial of higher degree.

In part (a) of the Example above, we multiplied a polynomial of degree one by a polynomial of degree three, and the product was a polynomial of degree four. In the Example part (b), the product of three first-degree polynomials is a third-degree polynomial.

assemblage.title: Degree of a Product
assemblage.p: The degree of a product of non-zero polynomials is the sum of the degrees of the factors. That is:
If P(x) has degree m and Q(x) has degree n, then their product P(x)Q(x) has degree m+n.

statement.p: What is the linear term of the product (x-3)(x+5) ?

solution.p: 2x is the linear term of x^2+2x-15.

statement.p:
Let P(x) = 5x^4 - 2x^3 + 6x^2 - x + 2, and Q(x) = 3x^3 - 4x^2 + 5x + 3.
What is the degree of their product? What is the coefficient of the lead term?
Find the coefficient of the x^3-term of the product.

li.p: The degree of P is 4, and the degree of Q is 3, so the degree of their product is 4 + 3 = 7. The only degree 7 term of the product is (5x^4)(3x^3) = 15x^7, which has coefficient 15.

In the product, each term of P(x) is multiplied by each term of Q(x). We get degree 3 terms by multiplying together terms of degree 0 and 3, or 1 and 2. For these polynomials, the possible combinations are:
The sum of the third-degree terms of the product is 34x^3, with coefficient 34.

statement.p: Find the coefficient of the fourth-degree term of the product of f(x) = 2x^6 + 2x^4 - x^3 + 5x^2 + 1 and g(x) = x^5 - 3x^4 + 2x^3 + x^2 - 4x - 2.

solution.p: 2 is the coefficient of the x^4 term in the product.

To compute the fourth-degree term in the product, we multiply a term of f(x) of degree 4, 3, 2, or 0 by a term of g(x) of degree 0, 1, 2, or 4 respectively. We add those four products of terms: \left(2x^4\cdot (-2)\right) + \left( (-x^3)(-4x)\right) + \left(5x^2\cdot x^2\right) + \left(1\cdot (-3x^4)\right) So the fourth-degree term in the product is 2x^4, and the coefficient is 2.

subsection.p: Another pair of products is useful for factoring cubic polynomials. In the Homework problems, you will be asked to verify the following products: (x + y)(x^2 - xy + y^2) \amp= x^3 + y^3 (x - y)(x^2 + xy + y^2) \amp= x^3 - y^3

subsection.title: Modeling with Polynomials
subsection.p: Polynomials model many variable relationships, including volume and surface area.

sidebyside.p: A closed box has a square base of length and width x inches and a height of 8 inches, as shown at right.

image.description: box with height inches with both length and width of x inches

li.p: Write a polynomial function S(x) that gives the surface area of the box in terms of the dimensions of the base.
What is the surface area of a box of length and width 18 inches?
The surface area of a box is the sum of the areas of its six faces, S = 2lh + 2wh + 2lw Substituting x for l and w, and 8 for h gives us S(x) = 2(8)x + 2(8)x + 2x^2 = 2x^2 + 32x
We evaluate the polynomial for x = 18 to find S(18) = 2(18)^2 + 32(18) = 1224 \text{ square inches}

subsection.p: Cubic polynomials are often used in economics to model cost functions. The cost of producing x items is an increasing function of x, but its rate of increase is usually not constant.

statement.p:
Pegasus Printing, Ltd. is launching a new magazine. The cost of printing x thousand copies is given by C(x) = x^3 - 24x^2 + 195x + 250
What are the fixed costs, that is, the costs incurred before any copies are printed?
Graph the cost function in the window below and describe the graph. \text{Xmin} \amp = 0 \amp\amp \text{Xmax} = 20 \text{Ymin} \amp = 0 \amp\amp \text{Ymax} = 1500
How many copies can be printed for $1200?
What does the concavity of the graph tell you about the cost function?

li.p: Fixed costs are given by C(0) = 250, or $250. The fixed costs include expenses like utility bills that must be paid even if no magazines are produced.
The graph is shown in figure (a). It is increasing from a vertical intercept of 250. The graph is concave down for x \lt 8 approximately, and concave up for x\gt 8.

image.description: GC graphs of a cubic cost function

li.p: We must solve the equation x^3 - 24x^2 + 195x + 250 = 1200 We will solve the equation graphically, as shown in figure (b). Graph y = 1200 along with the cost function, and use the intersect command to find the intersection point of the graphs, (15.319, 1200). C(x) = 1200 when x is about 15.319, so 15,319 copies can be printed for $1200.

Although the cost is always increasing, it increases very slowly from about x = 5 to about x = 11. The flattening of the graph in this interval is a result of economy of scale: By buying supplies in bulk and using time efficiently, the cost per magazine can be minimized. However, if the production level is too large, costs begin to rise rapidly again.

subsection.p: In c, we solved a cubic equation graphically. There is a cubic formula, cubic formula analogous to the quadratic formula, that allows us to solve cubic equations algebraically, but it is complicated and not often used.
Cubic polynomials are also used to model smooth curves connecting given points. Such a curve is called a cubic splinecubic spline.
